./.title: Introduction
./.body:
WarriorJS is a game that will put your JavaScript skills to the test.
You play as a warrior climbing a tall tower to [insert something motivating here] at the top level. On each floor, you must write JavaScript to instruct the warrior to battle enemies, rescue captives or do whatever it is necessary to reach the stairs alive.
WarriorJS Core extracts the mechanics of the original game, allowing you to build and share your own WarriorJS universes (with custom units, abilities and levels).



Inspiration
The original warriorjs is a ported version of ruby-warrior, developed with the intention of teaching JavaScript (and the at-the-time new ES2015 features) in a different way.
Installation
$ yarn add warriorjs-core

Documentation
Coming soon.
License
MIT

docs/game/Objective.html.title: Objective
docs/game/Objective.html.body:
Objective
As a player, you control the fate of a warrior climbing a tower by writing JavaScript code.
Your objective is to lead the warrior to the top of the tower.

docs/game/ThePlayerClass.html.title: The Player Class

docs/game/Playing.html.title: Playing
docs/game/Playing.html.body:
Playing
Once you are done editing the Player class, you are ready to start playing the level.
The play happens through a series of turns. On each one, your playTurn method is called along with the other unit's.
You cannot change your code in the middle of a level. You must take into account everything that may happen on that level and give your warrior the proper instructions from the start.
Losing all of your health will cause you to fail the level. You are not punished by this, you simply need to go back to the Player class, improve your code, and try again.
Reaching the stairs, on the other hand, will take your warrior to the next level.

docs/game/Scoring.html.title: Scoring
docs/game/Scoring.html.body:
Scoring
Your objective is to not only reach the stairs, but to get the highest score you can.
There are many ways you can earn points on a level:

defeat an enemy to add his max health to your score

pass the level within the bonus time to earn the amount of bonus time remaining

clear the level before climbing the stairs to receive a 20% overall bonus


In addition to that, some abilities can award points when used.

docs/core/concepts/.title: Concepts
docs/core/concepts/.body:
Concepts
In this section, we will explore the main concepts of WarriorJS Core:

Towers
Levels
Units
Warrior


Abilities
Effects

docs/core/concepts/units/Warrior.html.title: Warrior
docs/core/concepts/units/Warrior.html.body:
Warrior
The Warrior is the single most important unit in the game.
WIP

docs/core/concepts/Abilities.html.title: Abilities
docs/core/concepts/Abilities.html.body:
Abilities
Abilities are skills possessed by the units.
Although unit types have a fixed set of skills, abilities can also be assigned to specific units in a level. This is usually the case with your warrior. When you first start, your warrior will probably have only a few abilities which will grow with each level.
There are two kinds of abilities: actions and senses.
Actions
An action is a skill that affects the game in some way. Only one action can be performed per turn.
Senses
A sense is a skill used to gather information about a unit or space on the floor. You can perform senses as often as you want per turn to gather information about your surroundings and to aid you in choosing the proper action.

docs/core/concepts/Effects.html.title: Effects
docs/core/concepts/Effects.html.body:
Effects
Effects are a variety of conditions that can affect units in a positive or negative way. They are generally caused by abilities.

docs/core/api/.title: API Reference
docs/core/api/.body:
API Reference
This section documents the complete WarriorJS Core API.
Top-Level Exports

loadTower(tower)

Tower API

Tower
runLevel()



Unit API

Unit
type
maxHealth
health
position
isAlive()

earnPoints(points)
heal(amount)

Position API

Position
getRelativeSpace(relativeDirection, forward = 1, right = 0)
move(relativeDirection, forward = 1, right = 0)
rotate(relativeDirection)
getDistanceOf(space)
getDistanceFromStairs()
getRelativeDirectionOf(space)

Floor API

Floor

getUnits()
getOtherUnits()



Space API

Space
isWall()
isEmpty()
isStairs()
isWarrior()
isPlayer()
isEnemy()
isBound()

docs/core/api/loadTower.html.title: loadTower
docs/core/api/loadTower.html.body:
loadTower(tower)
Load a tower definition.
Arguments

tower (Object): An object containing the tower definition, with the following members:
abilities (Object): The abilities available to the units of the tower.
effects (Object): The effects available to the units of the tower.
units (Object): The units of the tower.
levels (Array): The list of levels in the tower.



Returns
(Tower): A fully loaded tower.

docs/core/api/Tower.html.title: Tower
docs/core/api/Tower.html.body:
Tower
Tower Methods
runLevel(levelNumber, warriorName, playerCode)
Run a level with a player's code.
Arguments

levelNumber (Number): The number of the level to run.
warriorName (String): The name of the warrior.
playerCode (String): The code written by the player. It should define a Player class with a playTurn(warrior) method.

Returns
(Object) An object containing the result of running the level, with the following members:

events (Array): The sequence of events that took place when running the level.
passed (Boolean): Whether the level was passed or not.
score (Object): The resulting score, with the following members:
clearBonus (Number): A bonus for defeating all enemies and rescuing all captives.
warrior (Number): The points earned by the warrior by killing units and rescuing captives.
timeBonus (Number): A bonus for completing the level in less than a specified amount of turns.

docs/core/api/Space.html.title: Space
docs/core/api/Space.html.body:
Space
A space is an object representing a square in the level.
Usually, spaces are returned from senses.
The methods in a space are useful to gather information about what is there.
Space Methods
isWall()
Determine if a wall is at that location. A wall is the edge of the level. You can't walk here.
Returns
(Boolean): Return true if the space is a wall.


isEmpty()
If a space is empty, this means that nothing (except maybe stairs) is at this location.
Returns
(Boolean): Return true if the space is empty.


isStairs()
Determine if stairs are at that location.
Returns
(Boolean): Return true if the space has the level stairs.


isWarrior()
Determine if the Warrior is at that location.
Returns
(Boolean): Return true if this space contains the Warrior.


isPlayer()
Determine if the Warrior is at that location. Alias of isWarrior().
Returns
(Boolean): Return true if this space contains the Warrior.


isEnemy()
Determine if an enemy unit is at this location.
Returns
(Boolean): Return true if this space contains an enemy unit.


isBound()
Determine if a bound unit is at this location.
Returns
(Boolean): Return true if this space contains a bound unit.


is(effect)
Determine if there is a unit at the space, and if that unit is affected by effect.
Arguments

effect (String): The name of the effect.

Returns
(Boolean): Return true if this space contains a unit with effect.

docs/build/GettingStarted.html.title: Getting Started
docs/build/GettingStarted.html.body:
Getting Started
WarriorJS Core defines a set of contracts that you have to implement in order to build a tower.
In this guide, we will cover each of them as we create a simple tower:

Ability
Effect
Unit
Level
Tower

docs/build/Ability.html.title: Ability
docs/build/Ability.html.body:
Ability
Abilities are plain JavaScript objects which have the following members:

type (String): The type of the ability. It can be either 'action' or 'sense'.
description (String): The description of the ability.
perform (Function): A function that defines how the ability operates.

As a tower maker, you will be writing functions that return abilities.
WIP
